subject: Re: [junit] Newbie question about the best practice for organizing 	and running tests
msgSnippet: ... In this case, you are doing functional testing, not unit testing. I still find that testing the internal workings of a class can help converge toward a bug
messageBody:
On Thu, Mar 26, 2009 at 8:41 AM, Nat Pryce <nat.pryce@...> wrote:
>
> I find it helpful to put unit tests in their own directory but in a
> *different* package from the code under test so that they must test
> through the object's public API and cannot cheat by using members with
> package-scope visibility. I find it gives me quicker feedback on API
> design issues.

In this case, you are doing functional testing, not unit testing.

I still find that testing the internal workings of a class can help
converge toward a bug faster, so putting the tests in the same package
as the code under test or relaxing the visibility of certain methods
(typically, to "package") helps testing at a lower level.

--
